creator: slive@apache.org
text:
No problem filing the report here.  It is true we don't have a better place.

But I don't understand why you would want to ssh tunnel an anonymous connection.
Just to assure the authenticity of the server?  Perhaps, but if you are
very concerned about that, you probably should be using release builds with
PGP signatures rather than retrieving from cvs.  There is no telling what
is in a cvs repository at any point in time.

The idea is to keep an as low profile as possible - if my ISP/SysAdmin has no
need to know what exactly I am downloading from apache, why should they learn?
Especially if the technical means to prevent this are already in place and
unless the anoncvs server is close to its computational limits, the extra cost
is negligible. Anyway, this is less an integrity than a privacy issue.

Principle: Leave as little traces as you can - all the time. 
Sounds a bit paranoid, I know ;)  but unfortunately I guess this won't be a
prudent behaviour for everybody in the coming years... minimization of exposure.
creator: hauser@acm.org
slive@apache.org
text:
OK.  I understand.

But I'm going to mark this wont-fix for a couple reasons:

1. We don't offer this for regular web access, I don't see why we would
encourage it for anonymous cvs access.

1. This kind of documentation should be kept as simple and straightforward as
possible.  Adding extra complication for something that is of limited use to
most people is not a good idea.

Thanks for your suggestion.

creator: hauser@acm.org
text:
Is not getting a certificate for https a formal decision? 
Seeing your "WON'T FIX" I'll not post an RFE for that since you apparently
consider privacy of "limited use to most people".
For integrity reasons, I suggest to reconsider https at least for the
ingredients to the PGP signatures you mention (see
http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=15622).

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
SSL is certainly something we are looking into, for numerous reasons, including
better access to the KEYS file.  But it won't happen quickly, because it
brings up lots of issues.

Other communities seem to be doing even the "privacy part" already:
see http://www.openbsd.org/anoncvs.html - in line with their "Secure by Default"
principle (http://www.openbsd.org/security.html#default).

And hopefully soon also http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=58251
creator: hauser@acm.org
slive@apache.org
text:
OK.  My opinion remains that this is not something we need to recommend
to most individuals.  But in case someone else feels differently, I will
reopen this bug.

For the same purpose, a password-less approach to also consider is described in
http://kitenet.net/programs/sshcvs/ 
Probably needs a second login (e.g. anoncvs_nopass) 

Suggestion: provide this option too and document it in the above page.
